instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: Having some issue isolating an issue on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>. No liquid damage, no visible damage. Sent to me, orange light, no boot. Opened it up, no fan, tested no <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present. Any ideas. Tried a monkey see monkey do at <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and changed it. No s0 at pin 16, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL>=8.56v. There looked to be some discoloration around the chip, so that's what prompted me to switch it out. No such luck. Ideas?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message:
Why are you checking S0 when there probably is not even S3?

Check for pulse on L7520 when connecting power. Check all rails for shorts.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: There is no pulse at L7520, this is assuming my scope is set right... There is not short on that rail either.  It looks like, it has a direct line from the connector to the io to L7520... Nothing there either.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: Also, is it not pertinent to go in the order of which they are listed on the schematic, as they will not be present without the rail prior? [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER]

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message:
Always go in order from
G3H RAIL or <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
Rtc rail
5v rail,  s5, s3, s0
3v rail, s5, s4, s3, s0
And so on..at least I did..

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: Any idea what could cause s3 not to be present? No shorts on circuit. Struggling to determine, why it isn't coming from the connector in the first place. Is it because of IO board (unlikely) or is it because of another component up stream?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: Was this a liquid damaged board? RTC voltages present on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>/1/2/3?

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: yes there is voltage on all, and resistance checks out. It seems as thought it was liquid damaged, but the shop before me US cleaned it... They dont mess with the board beyond that though.

threads.title: No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> 00165
threads.message: Where was the liquid? Check <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 clock chip. Check shorts to GND on all coils. Check for power cycling again on L7520
